bunpro.writeup: Functioning as an extension ofである, the formal copula that is a combination of theconjunctive formof theauxiliary verbだ, and the う-Verb ある,であれorであろうとwill be used in order to express strong will or conviction.あれ is simply theimperative formof ある, while あろうと is the positive volitional form combined with the case-marking particle と. Both structures are usually translated as 'even if (A), (B)', or 'no matter if (A), (B)'. Despite this, the more literal meaning of each is closer to 'so it's (A), (B) still won't be affected'. This just emphasizes the fact that (A) is of no relation to the result, like saying 'so what if it is' in English.Bothであれandであろうとwill primarily attach to nouns in sentences that express some kind of question or assumption through words like どんな or たとえ.As bothであれandであろうとuse structures that indicate strong will, these grammar patterns will frequently be used in sentences where the speaker is expressing their opinions or resolutions.

examples.japanese: 子供であれ、法律は守らなくてはいけない。
examples.english: Even if you are a child, you still need to obey the law.

examples.japanese: 理由が何であれ、家族や友達を裏切るのはよくないと思う。
examples.english: No matter the reason, I don't think it is right to betray your family and friends.

examples.japanese: いくらあなたが年上であろうと、ここでは一応私が先輩なので私の言うことに従ってください。
examples.english: No matter how much older you are, I am your superior here so please do as I say.

examples.japanese: 上司からのメール：インフルエンザであろうと、会社にはきてください。
examples.english: Email from one's boss: 'Even if you have the flu, please come to work.'

examples.japanese: 友人の家であれ、訪問時は靴を脱ぐことが、基本的な礼儀です。
examples.english: Even if it is a friend's house, taking shoes off when visiting are basic manners.

examples.japanese: 小説：「どのような状況であれ、逃げることは許されない。」
examples.english: Novel: 'No matter the circumstances, running away is unforgivable.'

examples.japanese: たとえ氷のように純粋であれ、世界の悪からは免れられないだろう。
examples.english: Even if one is as pure as ice, it seems that one cannot avoid the evil of the world.

examples.japanese: 誰であれ全ての人々は同様に死ぬ。
examples.english: No matter who you are, all people die similarly.

examples.japanese: たとえ小さなものであれ検察官は賄賂を受け取るわけにはいかない。
examples.english: Even if it is just a small thing, the public prosecutor must not accept a bribe.

dojg.description: A conjunctive phrase that expresses the idea of concession.
dojg.meaning: Even; even if; even though; no matter what/who/how/etc.~ may be; whatever/whoever/etc.~ may be

examples.japanese: (ksa).たとえ社長であれ、そのような行為は許されない。
examples.english: Even the (company) president shouldn't  be allowed to do things like that. (literally: Even if it is the president,  such conduct should not be allowed.

examples.japanese: (ksb).どんな問題であれ、必ず私に報告して下さい。
examples.english: Whatever kind of problem it may be, please report it to me  without fail.

examples.japanese: (ksc).通勤がいかに不便であれ、今の家を変わるつもりはない。
examples.english: No matter how inconvenient my commute  is, I do not intend to move (literally: from our current house).

examples.japanese: (ksd).いかに難しい問題であれ、彼ならきっと解決できるはずだ。
examples.english: No matter how difficult the problem may be, he certainly should  be able to solve it.

examples.japanese: (a).この練習は、たとえ数分間であれ、毎日することが大切です。
examples.english: It is important to practice this every day, even if it is only  for a few minutes.

examples.japanese: (b).彼の提言は、たとえそれが実行不可能であれ、聞くに値する。
examples.english: His suggestions are worth listening to even if they cannot be  carried out.

examples.japanese: (c).暗号技術については、たとえ短期間の使用であれ、その輸出入を規制している国があります。
examples.english: Some countries regulate the export and import of cryptographic  technology, even when it is intended for short-term use.

examples.japanese: (d).何事であれ、その仕事で生活するとなれば楽なものはない。
examples.english: Whatever kind it may be, if you make a living from it, there is  no such thing as easy work.

examples.japanese: (e).どのような理由であれ、著作物を複製する時は、著作権の侵害に注意しなければならない。
examples.english: Whatever the reason (for making copies) may be, when you  duplicate copyrighted materials, you have to be careful not to infringe on the  copyright.

examples.japanese: (f).当時の軍隊では上官の命令がいかに理不尽であれ、下級兵はそれに従うしかなかったのだ。
examples.english: In the army in those days, no matter how unreasonable the  senior ofﬁcers' commands, the soldiers under them had no choice but to obey  them.
